Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stabilized Organic Carbon and Paleoenvironmental Interpretations of Late Quaternary Paleosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Stabilized Organic Carbon and Paleoenvironmental Interpretations of Late Quaternary Paleosols

Michael Thompson, Iowa State University, EAR-1226949
Elmer Bettis III, University of Iowa, EAR-1226412
Rolfe Mandel, Kansas University, EAR-1226757
Jingdong Mao, Old Dominion University, EAR-1226323

ABSTRACT
Paleosols are widespread archives of paleoenvironmental information. Many Quaternary paleosols are laterally extensive, readily correlated, and suggestive of periods of regional climatic or geomorphic stability. This grant focuses on organic matter (OM) in paleosols. The objectives of this grant are (1) to identify and rank the importance of mechanisms of OM stabilization at the millennial scale, and (2) to significantly refine paleovegetation reconstructions of midcontinent, Late-Quaternary environments. At five sites in Kansas and Nebraska, OM will be studied in buried paleosols as old as 44.6 ka. These paleosols were chosen (1) to characterize paleosol organic matter in the two most widespread surficial materials in the Midcontinent (alluvium and loess), (2) to compare OM that has witnessed primarily aerated conditions (loess soils) with OM that has been subjected to alternating aerated and saturated condition (alluvial soils); (3) to systematically lengthen the periods in which OM has been buried, giving opportunity for early diagenetic changes to occur; and (4) to capitalize on information available from previous studies.
This project will improve understanding of which components of soil organic matter are preserved over millennial time scales and why they are preserved. Such understanding will inform reconstructions of Quaternary paleoenvironments and landscapes that are based on OM-hosted proxies. Of particular interest is the hypothesis that a significant component of stable carbon in paleosols consists of charcoal.
By evaluating the significance of charcoal in paleosol OM, the roles that fire can play in carbon storage, landscape evolution, and interpretations of paleoclimate can be elucidated. Because some forms of OM bind together mineral particles, paleosol OM components may regulate the ability of sediments to resist erosion, thus impacting landscape evolution. The research will also help to refine geochemical models that predict the amount of carbon that can be effectively sequestered in soils and provide new insights concerning the long-term stability of terrestrial OM and its impact on global carbon cycles.
This project will broaden participation of underrepresented groups in earth sciences through collaboration with colleagues and students at Alabama A&M Univ. AAMU students be invited to join the research team during summer sessions as part of ISU's George Washington Carver Summer Internship program and they will be recruited for graduate studies at Iowa State Univ. and Univ. of Iowa.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this study was to refine knowledge of organic matter in buried paleosols in the US Midwest and to use that knowledge to interpret paleoenvironments at the time of burial and since burial. We also hoped to advance general understanding of how organic matter is stabilized in sediments over thousands of years. By documenting the environments that lead to OM preservation in paleosols, we hope to provide meaningful, long-term data that can inform and constrain models of terrestrial carbon dynamics.

 

Since atmospheric carbon plays such an important role in climate science, carbon models are used to make global predictions about the mechanisms and likelihood of climate change. Citizens are concerned about the potential impacts of global change on food production, water quality and quantity, and ecosystem balance. They are concerned about the quality of human life and long-term stewardship of earth's resources. Improved models of carbon dynamics may increase citizen confidence in predictions about food production, water quality, and quantity, and ecosystem balance as climates and ecosystems evolve in the coming century.

 

The project was intended to provide information to mprove the reliability and precision of long-term predictions about the fate of buried soil organic matter and thus to improve models of terrestrial carbon dynamics over time-scales of centuries to millennia.

 

Our goals in this project were to assess mechanisms of organic matter stabilization in paleosols and to improve reconstructions of Late Quaternary paleovegetation. We found that long-term storage of organic carbon in the buried surface horizons of the paleosols of this study did not appear to be controlled by the association of soil organic matter with minerals such as layer silicates or Fe oxides. Rather, organic carbon storage in buried these paleosols appears to be a reflection of slow decomposition and cycling of organic carbon in microbial biomass. It is likely that microbial degradation was very slow since the time of burial (several thousand years ago). After burial, microorganisms continued to degrade plant residues into low molecular weight carbon compounds. Much of the organic carbon observed in the buried paleosols may be carbon that had been assimilated by microbes.

 

Episodes of rapid loess deposition and deposition of alluvium in floodplain sites during the early to mid-Holocene reduced the effect of environmental conditions that would increase the degradation process by microorganisms. The isolation from oxygen would have slowed the decomposition rate of the original plant materials as well as the rate of recycling of organic carbon produced by microbial activities. Hence, the carbon present in the paleosols was likely organic carbon that was turning over at a very slow rate. Still, the carbon concentration was gradually but continually reduced, as microbial activity depleted organic carbon compounds for energy.

 

In addition to the scientific goals, this project sought to improve the performance and skills of members of underrepresented groups that will improve their access to or retention in research, teaching, or other related professions. For example, the three students who have completed their theses on the project have come from underrepresented groups. In addition, the project benefitted from micromorphological analyses conducted by Dr. Monday Mbila, a faculty member at Alabama A&M and a collaborator on this project.
